text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]T_1: \mathbb R^7 \rightarrow \mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]T_2: \mathbb R^3 \rightarrow \mathbb R^7[/mathjaxinline] are both linear transformations.

font.p: Note that [mathjaxinline]T_1\circ T_2[/mathjaxinline] first applies [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline] and then [mathjaxinline]T_1[/mathjaxinline], so we need to check that the image of [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline] lies in the domain of [mathjaxinline]T_1[/mathjaxinline]. This is true since [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline] outputs a vector in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^7[/mathjaxinline], which is the domain of [mathjaxinline]T_1[/mathjaxinline]. Then, since [mathjaxinline]T_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline] are both linear transformations, so it [mathjaxinline]T_1\circ T_2[/mathjaxinline].

Now, [mathjaxinline]T_2\circ T_1[/mathjaxinline] first applies [mathjaxinline]T_1[/mathjaxinline], which outputs a vector in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline]. It would then apply [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline], but this is not possible since the domain of [mathjaxinline]T_2[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].
